Input: Tom had to decide how to treat all of his food for the week.  For starters, he bought 12 lbs of beans and 2 lbs of green beans to feed 4 people. Input: The bank gave a customer a check for $1500.  The customer told the teller the deposit was a gift, but later said he didn't know of any recipients.  A couple of weeks after the customer returned the check that was worth $1500, he saw the check in the bank's deposit box. Thinking this was a gift, he went to the deposit box and retrieved it. The teller asked him to come back a few days later to verify the account.  When a few days later the teller called the customer to verify the account, he said the gift check had bounced and they couldn't process the check.  The teller then asked him to come back six months later to verify the account, and he came the following day.  The teller asked him for his check number and he replied, "Never used my account number!"  The teller then left the room and the customer went to the bank's deposit box and retrieved the check.  The bank then cancelled all the accounts associated with the original check, but there was nothing in the account.
Output: 16

Some popular programming mistakes involve assigning an "opaque value" to a variable. For some programming languages, opaque variables are particularly dangerous. Consider the C programming language:

The obvious problem with such a variable is that it is difficult to read or maintain by others; furthermore, any other programming language can do away with such a language variable. The second issue is that variables are sometimes difficult to change without modifying the code, and modifying the code can break (or prevent) some types of programming programs.

If a Democrat has a net support of only one electoral vote, there is no chance of he being elected president. All states must award electors to that candidate according to the rules in their respective state laws, and it is not the responsibility of the electors to choose the candidate whom they wish. Input:What is a standard deviation?
Output: The standard deviation is a percent of all results that fall outside the range of the mean of two or more points. The "mean" is a percentage of all points in which the values fall within the average range. The range of averages is equal to the number of points away from the average. The range of results outside the range of averages is also equal to the number of values outside of the mean. In other words, the standard deviation is the percent that is outside of the range of averages for all values. The standard deviation is 1% for values greater than or equal to the average. For values between the average and the range of averages is 5%. For values greater than this and less than 5% there is no standard deviation. For values between the range of averages and the range of extremes the number is 25%. The more information you have about a statistic the more data you can obtain and make more accurate.

B Note I - B is a very useful note.

This is the right answer.  It says that they worked 4 hours and then they joined by 6 other people - not four people working at the same rate as them - and so the work took 6 hours total even though the 4 people did all their actual work by the end of the day.  The other 6 spent more time waiting for the other 6 that actually did the work.  The 4 people who left with the 6 spent nearly all their time outside of work doing something they may not have been interested in or even able to get done in a full day's time.  As a result, all the 6 people spent more time waiting for them than actually working.

Note the order of operations in the problem. We are asking people to put together these four facts (in this case the above four facts) in a way that makes it easy to remember and use.  Then we give them the answers because it's easy to remember and it's really easy to use.

input:"To" is a special case of the expression, "from", that can only be used with one or more variables. The expression "(from) to" will work for multiple variables.

input"To" is a special formality, the same as "to" or "to me" in text and "to" or "too" or "too me" in spoken conversation.  In informal writing, "to" can be preceded by a verb, a prefix, a name, an adverb, an adjective, or more rarely a pronoun or adjective with its corresponding gender and/or pronoun. In formal writing, when used to begin a phrase, it is followed by another word. In other writing, it may follow by either a noun, adjective, or pronoun.

input"From" is a special case that is used only with one or more variables in a formula or expression.

input"I" is a special form of the verb "be" in a sentence.

input"to" refers to the use of the pronoun "he".

input"too" refers to the use a pronoun or adjective in the place of "me" when speaking to oneself.

Input: A farmer sells one-month-old calves to a dairy company.  During the past year, the farmer lost $12,000 in the market.  When the farmer goes to sell his calves, he gets a new contract to supply two herds owned by the same dairy at a lower price.  If the farmer sold his calves to the new dairy for $8 per head in 2011, and the total price of selling the calves was $13 per head in 2012, the total cost of the farmer's 2012 cattle sales was $13,200.  If Adam sold his calves to the same dairy without changing a price, the total cost of selling his 2010 cattle would be the same as the cost of selling his 2012 cattle.  To estimate the price of selling the 2010 cattle in 2010, calculate the difference between the price in 2010 and the price in 2011.  To figure out the price of selling the 2012 cattle, calculate the difference between $13 in 2012 and $10 in 2010.  To calculate 2011 prices, add back 2011's $12k and $14k to $13k.  Then add back 2010's $12k and 2011's $13k.  That brings his total income to $16,200.  Assuming that his 2008 income is zero, Adam would earn $2k per year more in 2012. That would take him to a total income of $22k, or more than $800 higher than his 2008 total, even though the entire income increase is due to gains from selling the 2010 cattle.
Output: $10,841 (+ $2,000)

Output: The total number of trees planted in the U.S. during the 20th century was roughly 100 billion or about one-third of the total number of trees planted the previous century (see the article “The United States: Natural Resources’ Boom: The Slicing of the United States”).  If we multiply the total number of trees at the turn of the century, we get something like 100 billion trees planted over the next 50 years or so.  If we multiply the trees planted by the population of the nation, we get something like a billion trees per nation. In other words, the tree planting rate was about 200 billion trees planted per year in the twentieth century.  The tree planting rate grew strongly as population increased in the twentieth century, and will likely grow even further.  This trend is a strong factor affecting the climate and will significantly affect the rate of climate change.  Globalization is driving this trend.  This is part of the global warming problem.
Output: 120 billion

If they are running or running home, they should not get too close.  If you are running, you may be too close, but you are not allowed to pass them or they cannot pass you.  You are also not allowed to talk to them, or to get a feel a for their pace because of the risk of being passed and, in many instances, being slowed down. In any circumstance, do not try to catch up because they may be the only one out there who is doing a reasonable pace. Make sure that you are not too tired to run at the end of your run or you may be passed. Most people do not run the entire distance of their run and the majority of their time is spent walking.  If you have to get up in the middle of your workout to go to the bathroom, keep going. Keep in mind that you will not get a full two miles by walking or just running. You can see how this works; you see how your problem is asking you to get from a point to a place you need to be.  So if the equation requires that you use the second method, just do that, and if you are working to get from A to B, don't rely on A being the only way to get from A to b in the first place.  You have to calculate the required times from both methods, and combine both times to get the answer.

You can do this exercise on a computer or a calculator, either way it is a good exercise because you are only getting 5 out of 36 questions, and this will get you to do them in less than 5 minutes!

Comments

The above questions should be put into practice in everyday life for at least a couple of weeks on your travels, to see how you learn. If you are a student you should give as many examples of questions as is possible and then add your own experience and thoughts on them.

For example, let’s start off by looking at a situation with alcohol related spending from the real world. It was not long ago that it was common to go out drinking with friends on a Friday night without worrying about spending much money, but the days of going out and spending hundreds or thousands of dollars without worrying are gone. More and more people are finding it more efficient to buy their alcohol online, or get it drunk at home if it is a weekend night out. If you are someone who doesn’t want to buy alcohol from the Internet then you will need to spend more than an average person.

By going the route of buying alcohol at home you will need to start to be more economical with your spending, and even if you get drunk at home it is likely that you will have to be more responsible with your drinking than in the past. Even if you just look at the numbers then you can see how important alcohol is to your lifestyle, and in addition to that alcohol really does not fit in with a healthy and balanced lifestyle – just look at the obesity epidemic that we have in this country. Alcohol does take up a lot of our time, and often affects our relationships with people and the way we act in the other

The exercise is based on "Striking Distance: The Role and Impact of the Organization in Socio-Economic Growth" by Lillian K. Mather, Edith E. Goss, and James S. Laskowski, published in the journal Development Research.

The objectives of the exercise are to make students more aware of the need for the organization's role in economic growth and development as well as to recognize how some problems might be resolved more effectively if organizational structures were reformed.

The exercise also seeks to prepare students for a more critical examination of a problem and to understand how people can be more effective in addressing these problems.

Input: A young couple goes on a long vacation.  They decide to build a house in the sand.  They have decided the house must have a basement with a waterway under it.  They know how they are going to build the house so they begin to build the basement.  They are about half-way finished when they decide that they would rather finish their house.  They decide to call a guy from Chicago who works on water projects and tells them the plans and tells them to go ahead and finish their own house.  The couple does exactly as instructed.  They were not happy with the plans but the guy promised them they would be happy with the original plans.  The couple called a second guy who had done much of a water project for another client and the couple was even more unhappy.  They decided to call a third guy, with a company that could make better plans.  The couple began to change their plans.  They thought they were going to get the house they wanted but this third guy, who they had heard so much for, told them he had built a similar house where the water did not flow.  The couple decided they would have to start over and called the first guy again.  This guy took a look at their plans and realized how badly they need to change the plan.  He told them they need to start over, cut out a couple of layers of drywall and get back to building a house.  The couple got back to building and soon realized that what they had learned from the first guy would work.  They cut out a hole and brought the water to the basement.  They were shocked.  They realized that before they could get the water flowing the wet sand must be moved to hold the drywall.  Now they could not get the water flowing until the sand got a little warmer.  They could hold their breath just under the surface.  They kept holding their breaths as they took a look down.  They saw a little fish swimming around just beneath the surface of the water.  They were sure it was a dolphin or a whale.  However they knew that it was a fish and could not see any fins.  The fish was too big to be a dolphin and the fin looked like a whale head.  They had to have a conversation about the shape of the fish as they discussed it for a bit.  They said that it looked like a turtle and they felt it was right on the money with what they saw in nature.

D

Input:The sun and the moon rotate in opposite directions during every month of the year. A, B, C and D correspond to the full moon, minimum moon, full moon and a new moon respectively.
Output: -2

input/output questions for english class

A: The sun and moon are facing the same plane both at noon. The sun is closer to the Earth during summer and has a higher gravitational field. The moon is farther away and has a lower gravitational field.
Output: +2

B: The sun and the moon face away from each other as they rotate their orbits around Earth one day at a time. The sun is close to the Earth during summer when it has a higher gravitational field, while the moon is farther away and therefore has a lower gravitational field of about −3.5.
Output: -3

C: Each moon is made up of 60% of the sun's mass, resulting in a larger body relative to the Earth's orbit. As the moon orbits the Earth, it draws closer to the Earth each day. Because it does not have to deal with the sun's gravity it orbits farther away. This creates a different gravitational field for each day, resulting in differing rotational velocities for any given day. If each day of a moon's orbit is represented by the same velocity it would appear to travel at the same speed of 2.0 mph in a day but would actually be moving at 7.0 mph, or a speed of over 400% faster.
Output: +3

D: The moon's orbit is closer to the Earth than the sun's. As the moon continues to orbit the Earth, its angular orientation relative to the Earth's axis changes as the moon reaches its apogee and perigee. Consequently, the moon's rotation remains the same but the relative direction of its orbital motion varies. If the moon were to remain in one position relative to the Earth, at one particular location on the face of the Earth, it would appear to move at the speed of 2.0 m/sec. But instead, it would move around the Earth in many planes, with each plane having its own velocity. Therefore, it would appear to be traveling at a speed of 7.0 m/sec instead of the original 2.0 m/Sec due to the difference in the velocity of each plane.
Output: +1

However, before he could lose his family, a bank manager walked in on his wife and demanded that Wilkie pay their debt against their home. Wilkie told him that he could do that with the money that he stole as he had never had children and would not have wanted Wilkie's if he ever did. The banker told Wilkie that he would never accept his explanation. Wilkie then returned home with his wife and child and refused to give up his "stolen wealth". After being told by multiple people that he had lost his family due to his deception, Wilkie finally told the truth by admitting that he had simply needed to steal the money in order to care for his family. In the end Wilkie became a millionaire who treated his wife and child with respect and gave them everything that they needed. What is the lesson of this story?
Input: Always be truthful and honest with yourself, your spouse/child/manager/agent.
Output: 7/10

Question is worded a bit like this (from memory):
1. Where is a lion likely to be?
2. Where are lions likely to stay?
3. How likely is the lion to escape?
4. How likely is the car to be stolen?
5. How likely is the house to get robbed?
6. How likely is the road to get blocked?
7. How likely is the child to get abducted?
8. How likely is the marriage to work out?
9. How likely is the job opportunity to pay well?
10. How likely is the community to grow?
11. Where do you think God's house is likely to be?
12. What do you think of the following statement:
"There are plenty lions. The most important question that is asked by the lions is, 'Are you going to eat me?' "

First off all, the question asks the individual to state what the lion thinks of the situation. There is a problem with it as it does not state what the actual question might be in the case of a hypothetical situation (like a hypothetical situation in which everyone is killed by a lion). The first two options are not entirely accurate but the third and last few are rather inaccurate considering that the lion will be a very busy one! A better format would be:

1. Where is the lion likely to be?  2. Where are lions likely (to) stay?  3. How many lions will be killed by (a hypothetical situation, like a hypothetical situation in which every single one of us is killed by a lion)? 4. How likely is the ( hypothetical situation, like a (hypothetical situation, like a (Hypothetical (hypothetical (hypothetic /) hypotheticals ).

This gives both the lions and the hypothetical individuals time to answer without losing a point.  There is no question of the lions thinking the question or anything else.

Thanks,
Cheryl

PS - I've just realized that the's' at the end of the question is not there:

Answer: The first two options are entirely false. The lion does not need a question, as he does not need anything in

12

The sisters think for a moment about this and then reject this idea saying that they don't want to live in a city, they want to live in their village. The only reason that the two sisters would want to move to the city is for the men to make their own decisions, have fun and find happiness for themselves. A skier falls into the middle of the canyon and is unable to swim out of the canyon before going under and eventually drowning.  When Bob was young, at night he and his brother would go with their dog to watch the skiers.  Every night they would run their dogs over the bridges near the side of the canyon.  As time went on, the bridges became worn down and were no longer safe; it had started to freeze over.  The skiers would not notice the falling dog, but Bob and his brother would.  Bob's mother was on a trip out of town and her car stopped at the bridge about 50 feet up.  The bridge began to slide down toward the canyon.  Bob grabbed her hand and pulled her onto the bridge.  The boat had just enough time to head over the bridge to the other side but was too small a boat to make the turn.  The water in the canyon was quite deep and would drown anyone in the boat. 1. 42 kg is about the same as 12 lbs
2. 12 lbs is about twice as much as 3 kg
3. 18 kg is about 2 times as much as 1 kg
4. The higher the price, then the greater cost
5. The lower the price, then the lesser cost
6. The same is true for other goods such as seeds, oil and water.

and was used to compare one market with another.)

Input:There are two types of cells: red blood cells and white blood cells. Red blood cells are produced in the bone marrow. The stem cells in the bone marrow, called mesenchymal progenitors, have two distinct qualities: 1) they develop quickly, with great capacity to divide and 2) they divide by cell division into many different types of cell, which are all good for the body to use. Red blood cells in their turn develop as quickly as possible in large amounts and thus they can be re-used on a regular basis. White blood cells are produced in a gland in the skin called the thymus gland. White blood cells contain many different genes, and can divide many times before they become useless, as they are the last line of defense of the body. The human body has a large amount of both types of cells, even in the absence of infections.
What is the percentage of red blood and white blood cells in the human population? What is the population's average total number of red blood cells and what is the normal number of white blood cells?
Output: 2% + 2% = 10.4%

Input:It was the third week in April and the temperature was at its hottest. At daybreak a young man and girl were out on a boat. They were enjoying the sunshine and the sea breeze.   The boy had put out a fishing line and his brother had caught a fish.  The girl was holding a baby who was having a great time in the water.  The woman and her friend were about to join them a sudden storm ripped up the boat and sent her into the sea.  It took all her strength just to stay afloat.  The young man was holding the baby while the girl was trying to grab hold of him.  The man and woman, still in the water held the baby tight, not letting go.  After a while they got to shore the boy’s mom came down and told the girl to grab hold of the boy so she could get out of the water.  By this time the baby had stopped crying, but the mom was having quite a struggle.  At one point her feet slipped and she fell into the water.  The man and the woman were now having even more trouble because the baby had managed to climb back out and onto the boat.  All of them were worried about her and the baby was crying louder than ever.  Finally on the 5th hour of the storm the boater came over to see what had become of the mother.  “How is your daughter doing?” he asked. A few hours later two people reached up to try and rescue the girl. A huge piece of rock had come loose and had fallen onto her little body.  The two people picked her up grabbed her and then jumped into the sea.  Within a few minutes the rescue team had found the girl and handed her to her parents.  Finally only four hours later the rescue team had finally rescued the boy.  After they had done it he went home with his brother. How much is it estimated both of them spent? The answer:   2.6 million dollars.
Output: 42

Input:The human eye consists of a central region which contains the retina, cornea and a clear lens. The eye is about the size of a football, but it contains 6 million cells and each cell can hold over 10 000 photos. At peak illumination the eye can see about 3 000 light bulbs. To maintain a constant depth perception for a person with an ocular disease the eye must be able to reflect more light than it absorbs, the more light reflected back the better the vision. This is known as dark vision syndrome. If the eye had no reflective surface it would be less efficient, which would mean that photosynthetic organisms produce more light. In order to compensate for the darkness generated by cloudy conditions the eye of the person with a condition would have to produce about twice as much energy as a normal human with no condition would. This is known as the photodetector. The eye's photodetectors are very efficient in the glare of the sun, and the light they collect is sent to the brain via a complex circuit of pathways. The signals received from the photodetectors then convert to electrical signals which are transmitted by the eye's optic nerve to the brain as inputs. It is the job of the brain to translate the signals received from the eyes muscles, which send stimuli to the brain as inputs, to information needed for visual vision. A person who has dark vision syndrome is visually impaired, but they maintain the ability to carry out normal everyday activities.
